title: Who's cutting hospital bed numbers?
subtitle: It’s been falling almost constantly since the 1980s, but there's more to these figures than meets the eye.
author: fullfact.org
vclaim:
“When hospitals are struggling to provide essential care why is the government cutting the number of beds in our National Health Service?” “Thanks to medical advances, to the use of technology, to the quality of care, what we see in hospital stays is actually that the average length of time for staying in hospital has virtually halved since the year 2000. But let us look at Labour’s record on this issue, in the last six years of the last Labour government, 25,000 hospital beds were cut”

The number of hospital beds has been falling over the past decade, regardless of who was in office.

The total number of overnight hospital beds in the English NHS has actually been falling almost constantly since the 1980s. It fell by about 26,000 in the last six years of the most recent Labour government as Mrs May says, and it’s still falling now as Mr Corbyn says.

It’s not clear that we need as many beds as we used to. The average length of stay has fallen since the turn of the century (though not quite by half). The average length of stay overnight in 2000 was about eight days, and it’s about five days now.

That said, the fact that we’re spending fewer nights in hospital doesn’t completely explain away why bed numbers are falling.

The proportion of beds that are occupied has been rising slowly since 2010. From July to September last year the proportion hit 87.5% — the highest recorded figure for that time of year. That’s higher than the safe level of 85% recommended by NHS Providers and the Royal College of Psychiatrists.
